name: TheAtlantic
text: Listen: Would defunding the police make us safer? @avitale joins @jameshamblin and @katlwells to discuss on the latest "Social Distance" podcast. https://t.co/4yRpsNNk8J

name: TheAtlantic
text: Amid a global pandemic and growing civil unrest, Los Angeles finally gave the green light for drive-in theaters to reopen. But going to one felt far from normal, @shirklesxp reports: https://t.co/CfzblB6sqz

name: TheAtlantic
text:
As you process the events of this past week, these perspectives from our writers might be helpful. The latest Atlantic Daily from @IsabelFattal: 
https://t.co/onfPQQNSZq

name: TheAtlantic
text: “This happened to Dad, this happened to Grandpa, this happened to Great Grandma,” is how one historian described to @jpinsk the pain and frustration that many black families are experiencing right now. https://t.co/3xftiYPU2U

name: TheAtlantic
text: Listen: Public-health experts have warned that the protests will lead to a spike in coronavirus infections, but what role does the policing of the protests play in that dynamic? @jameshamblin and @katlwells discuss on the latest "Social Distance" podcast. https://t.co/e8A8L7ogmj

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The inability to compromise at home is becoming the modus operandi overseas. In the past, a sense of common domestic purpose gave ballast to U.S. diplomacy; now its absence enfeebles it," William J. Burns writes. https://t.co/bU5dR8YoKJ

name: TheAtlantic
text: Here are 13 of the best films that translated real-life paranoia and government mistrust into thrilling and complicated cinema, according to @davidlsims: https://t.co/bcKpjUnbzq

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Biden’s continued advocacy of muddled and mistaken foreign policies shouldn’t be overlooked, and he can best help his cause by quietly rebooting them," @KoriSchake writes. https://t.co/scR5NNjARI

name: TheAtlantic
text: A new poem by @rblancopoet: "Say This Isn't the End." https://t.co/Nc6VzwccUD

name: TheAtlantic
text: "I’m a Woody Allen person, not because I disbelieve Dylan Farrow—in fact, I believe her. I’m a Woody Allen person because his movies helped shape me," @CaitlinPacific writes. https://t.co/hRMLCeFOMX

name: TheAtlantic
text: When people pass into myth, they lose dimension; the hard-earned lessons of their life are flattened into platitudes. Few people earned their lessons harder than Larry Kramer had to. @mthomps remembers his 2018 visit with the late AIDS activist: https://t.co/n3gZlU66bl

name: TheAtlantic
text: A shoddy computer system wrongly charged 40,000 people in Michigan with fraud. Six years later, the damage is still being undone, @Swykstr reports. https://t.co/nyESrOgEpn

name: TheAtlantic
text: HBO’s new series "I May Destroy You," by the British writer Michaela Coel, is an explosive examination of modern sexual mores and the limits of consent, @sophieGG writes: https://t.co/gkI3u4g77a

name: TheAtlantic
text: The demonstrations that have seized America’s cities have no national leader. There are only people, hundreds of thousands of them. And they could be there for months, writes @elainejgodfrey. https://t.co/pNCAmRueNj

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: "Everyone has been woken up by 2020.” https://t.co/NNbPZBcTeU

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @elainejgodfrey: The demonstrations that have seized America’s cities and towns have no national leader. There are only people, hundreds of thousands of them, spilling into streets, clogging bridges, and filling parks. And they could be marching for months.

New, from me: https://t.co/TgxYzddnsg

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: "It was the pulping of the books that really bothered me. No book burning, with all the trimmings? Banned books deserve the works: bonfire, weenies, the whole bit. You want to make a day of it—get the kids to come out." @CaitlinPacific's latest:   https://t.co/fXj5wHmVGH

text: RT @AdrienneLaF: A poem for Sunday, by @rblancopoet https://t.co/pe3OIyTc7r
